Schalk says what we're seeing is the brain's attempt to fill in the missing sounds.
The brain basically tells us a lot of information about the music in the times when there is really no music.
It's not played.
Schalk says ECoG is also revealing things about how the brain creates speech.
He and other researchers are using the technology to watch the brains of people as they speak out loud and also as they say the words silently to themselves.
One of the surprising initial findings coming out of that research was that actual and imagined speech is very, very different.
Schalk says when your brain wants you to say a word, it produces two sets of signals.
One has to do with moving your muscles.
And that makes sense.
First, you have to move your mouth around and your vocal tract around so as to produce a particular type of verbal output.
And there are also signals coming from the auditory system.
On the other hand, when a person simply thinks of a word instead of saying it, there are no muscle signals, just the activity in the parts of the brain involved in listening.
And that seems to suggest that what imagined speech actually really is, it's more like internally listening to your own voice.
